issue.description:
IBC SECTION 1012 RAMPS 1012_2 Slope (part of means of egress).
Ramp slope is 10.0%. The maximum slope for the ramps is 8.0%.
issue.title: Too Steep Ramp: 10.0%

suggestions.action: Reduce ramp slope to 8.0%.
suggestions.reasoning: The current ramp slope of 10.0% exceeds the maximum allowable slope of 8.0% as per IBC Section 1012.

suggestions.action: Implement a switchback design to reduce slope.
suggestions.reasoning: By redesigning the ramp as a switchback, we can maintain accessibility while adhering to the 8.0% slope requirement.

suggestions.action: Add landings to break up the slope.
suggestions.reasoning: Incorporating landings at intervals will allow the ramp to comply with the maximum slope while providing resting points for users.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.0.3 tread length is 0.20 m. The minimum length for the tread is 0.28 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.3: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Increase tread length to 0.28 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current tread length of 0.20 m does not meet the minimum requirement of 0.28 m.

suggestions.action: Redesign stair with a curved tread for aesthetic appeal and compliance.
suggestions.reasoning: A curved tread can enhance the design while ensuring it meets the minimum length requirement.

suggestions.action: Incorporate a modular tread system to allow for adjustable lengths.
suggestions.reasoning: A modular system can provide flexibility in design and ensure compliance with tread length regulations.

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Underside of stair should be shielded to protect visually impaired persons from accessing it inadvertently.
issue.title: Stair.0.3

suggestions.action: Install protective barriers beneath the stair.
suggestions.reasoning: To prevent visually impaired individuals from inadvertently accessing the stair area, a solid barrier should be installed beneath the stair.

suggestions.action: Implement visual and tactile indicators on the stair's underside.
suggestions.reasoning: Using bright colors and textured surfaces will alert visually impaired individuals to the stair's presence and guide them away.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair for increased vertical clearance.
suggestions.reasoning: Modifying the stair design can enhance safety by reducing the risk of accidental access for visually impaired individuals.

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Underside of stair should be shielded to protect visually impaired persons from accessing it inadvertently.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Install protective barriers along the underside of the stair.
suggestions.reasoning: The stair's height poses a risk to visually impaired individuals; protective barriers will prevent inadvertent access.

suggestions.action: Implement visual and tactile indicators on the stair's underside.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding contrasting colors or textures will alert visually impaired individuals to the presence of the stair.

suggestions.action: Enhance lighting around the stair area.
suggestions.reasoning: Improved lighting will increase visibility of the stair, helping visually impaired individuals to navigate safely.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair SStair.1448 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the required width of 0.90 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than 0.90 m, necessitating modifications to the existing stair landing and adjacent wall.

suggestions.action: Install a folding staircase to save space.
suggestions.reasoning: A folding staircase can provide access while allowing for flexibility in space usage, addressing the width issue creatively.

suggestions.action: Install a ramp as an alternative access solution.
suggestions.reasoning: A ramp can provide compliant access while accommodating mobility needs, utilizing the space around the existing stairs.

issue.description:
504.3 Open Risers
Stair SStair.1448 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the 0.90 m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than the required 0.90 m, which violates safety standards.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair landing as a curved shape to increase width without altering the overall footprint.
suggestions.reasoning: A curved landing can provide additional width while maintaining aesthetic appeal and functionality.

suggestions.action: Incorporate a foldable extension on the landing to temporarily increase width during peak usage.
suggestions.reasoning: A foldable extension can provide flexibility in space usage, allowing for compliance during high traffic times.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair SStair.1456 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.2.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to at least 0.90 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than the required 0.90 m, necessitating a modification to meet compliance.

suggestions.action: Install a foldable landing extension.
suggestions.reasoning: A foldable extension can provide additional width when needed, allowing for compliance without permanent structural changes.

suggestions.action: Add an adjacent stair or ramp for alternative access.
suggestions.reasoning: Providing an alternative route ensures compliance while accommodating the existing landing constraints.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.0.1 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.1: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Lower the riser height to 0.18 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height of 0.18 m, necessitating a reduction to comply with building code 504.2.

suggestions.action: Add intermediate landings to the stair design.
suggestions.reasoning: Introducing landings would allow for a gradual ascent, breaking the height into smaller segments and ensuring compliance with the maximum riser height.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair as a spiral staircase.
suggestions.reasoning: A spiral staircase can provide a compact solution that allows for compliance with riser height regulations while enhancing the aesthetic appeal of the space.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.2.1 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.2.1: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Reduce the riser height to 0.18 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height of 0.18 m as per building code 504.2.

suggestions.action: Install a stair lift for accessibility.
suggestions.reasoning: If reducing the riser height is not feasible, a stair lift can provide compliance and accessibility for users.

suggestions.action: Reconfigure the stair design to include a switchback.
suggestions.reasoning: A switchback design can reduce the height of each riser while maintaining the same vertical rise, ensuring compliance with the code.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.3.2 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Modify the riser height to 0.18 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height of 0.18 m.

suggestions.action: Introduce an intermediate landing between treads.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding a landing can break the height into smaller increments, enhancing safety and accessibility.

suggestions.action: Install stair lifts or ramps alongside the stair.
suggestions.reasoning: This provides an alternative means of access for individuals with mobility challenges, ensuring compliance with accessibility standards.

issue.description:

suggestions.action: Adjust riser height to 0.18 m

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Stair SStair.1448 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Increase landing width to 0.90 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than the required 0.90 m, necessitating an increase to meet compliance.

suggestions.action: Install a folding landing for flexibility.
suggestions.reasoning: A folding landing can provide the required clearance when needed while maintaining design aesthetics.

issue.description:
504.3 Open Risers
Stair SStair.197 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.1

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the 0.90 m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than the required 0.90 m, which does not comply with safety standards.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair landing as a curved or angled shape to increase width.

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the 0.90 m requirement.

issue.description:
504.3 Open Risers
Stair SStair.1114 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.3

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the 0.90 m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than 0.90 m, which does not comply with the regulations.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair landing as a curved shape to increase width without altering the overall footprint.

suggestions.action: Implement a tiered landing design to create usable space and meet width requirements.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.3.1 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.1: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Reduce the riser height to 0.18 m or lower.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height of 0.18 m, posing safety risks.

suggestions.action: Install adjustable modular stair components.
suggestions.reasoning: Using modular components allows for on-site adjustments to ensure compliance with riser height regulations.

suggestions.action: Add stair nosing for visibility and safety.
suggestions.reasoning: Installing stair nosing enhances safety by making the risers more visible and providing better grip.

issue.description:
405.2 Slope
Ramp length is 3.00 m and slope is 10.0%. The maximum length for this slope is 1.52 m.
issue.title: Ramp.0.1: 3.00 M

suggestions.action: Redesign the ramp to comply with slope regulations.
suggestions.reasoning: The current ramp length of 3.00 m exceeds the maximum allowable slope of 1.52 m, necessitating a redesign to ensure compliance.

suggestions.action: Incorporate landings along the ramp to reduce slope perception.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding landings would break up the slope, making it more manageable and compliant with accessibility standards.

suggestions.action: Consider adding an elevator or lift as an alternative access solution.
suggestions.reasoning: If redesigning the ramp is not feasible, an elevator would provide necessary access for individuals with mobility challenges.
